communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Beverly Jean Davenport LaHaye (April 30, 1929 – April 14, 2024)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Beverly Jean Davenport LaHaye (April 30, 1929 – April 14, 2024), née Ratcliffe, and the organization she founded, Concerned Women for America. Her death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find her New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/19/us/politics/beverly-lahaye-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an associate editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest for the Daily Beast, the Asia Times, Responsible Statecraft, the National Interest, America Magazine and the Armenian Weekly, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1643105-000
communications.communication:
To whom this may concern:

I hope this message finds you well. My name is Matthew Petti and I am writing with regard to my FOIA request number 1643105-000 for records on Beverly Jean Davenport LaHaye (April 30, 1929 – April 14, 2024), née Ratcliffe, and the organization she founded, Concerned Women for America. On August 13, 2024, Section Chief Michael G. Seidel wrote that, "In an effort to provide you with responsive records as expeditiously as possible, we are releasing documents from previous requests regarding your subject. We consider your request fulfilled. Since we relied on previous results, additional records potentially responsive to your subject may exist. If this release of previously processed material does not satisfy your request, you may request an additional search for records."

I am writing to request an additional search for records, both on Concerned Women for America and on Ms. LaHaye, its founder. Thank you for your cooperation and I look forward to hearing back soon.

Sincerely,
Matthew

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Prentice Marshall
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Prentice Henry Marshall (August 7, 1926 - May 24, 2004). Proof of death is not required as his death was widely reported: https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/28/us/prentice-marshall-77-federal-judge-dies.html. Marshall was one of the judges hearing cases related to Operation Greylord.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. This is also to include any responsive records held in offsite locations, such as the Alexandria Records Center. Please include both investigatory and non-investigatory records in your search. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1474955-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 104 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 853 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,786 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,500 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

COVID-19 Impact: RIDS resumed full staffing on April 12, 2021.  Commensurate with the return of full staffing levels, RIDS will being increasing its FOIA processing production.  While RIDS will make its best efforts to meet increased production goals, this increased production rate may be negatively impacted by COVID-19 workplace disruptions.  As a result, estimated dates of completion for Freedom of Information Act requests were impacted and you can expect lengthened response timelines.  Please note that these are estimates, and these timelines may change as this national emergency evolves.  The FBI remains committed to fulfilling your FOIPA request in the timeliest manner possible.   Thank you for your patience and understanding.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Metcalf Attack
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern:

This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act. I hereby request the following records:

Any and all documents pertaining to the 16 April 2013 attack on PG&E's Metcalf substation near San Jose, CA including but not limited to the attack's effects on agency policy and incident response.

This request seeks documents including but not limited to: reports, threat and intelligence assessments, slide presentations, meeting minutes, memoranda, and emails.

This request is not meant to be exclusive of any other records which, though not specifically requested, would have a reasonable relationship to the subject matter of this request.

The timeframe for this request encompasses 16 April 2013 up to and including the date that this request is officially processed.
If my request is denied in whole or part, I ask that you justify all deletions by reference to specific exemptions of the act. I will also expect to be provided with all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material. Please separately state your reasons for not invoking your discretionary powers to release the requested documents in the public interest.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Daniel Boguslaw

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1490938-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 104 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 853 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,786 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,500 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

COVID-19 Impact: RIDS resumed full staffing on April 12, 2021.  Commensurate with the return of full staffing levels, RIDS will being increasing its FOIA processing production.  While RIDS will make its best efforts to meet increased production goals, this increased production rate may be negatively impacted by COVID-19 workplace disruptions.  As a result, estimated dates of completion for Freedom of Information Act requests were impacted and you can expect lengthened response timelines.  Please note that these are estimates, and these timelines may change as this national emergency evolves.  The FBI remains committed to fulfilling your FOIPA request in the timeliest manner possible.   Thank you for your patience and understanding.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Paul Norton "Pete" McCloskey Jr. (September 29, 1927 – May 8, 2024)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into former U.S. congressman Paul Norton "Pete" McCloskey Jr. (September 29, 1927 – May 8, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/08/us/politics/pete-mccloskey-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an associate editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest for the Daily Beast, the Asia Times, Responsible Statecraft, the National Interest, America Magazine and the Armenian Weekly, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1634653-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request

If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-0] please enter [1195846-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-1] please enter [1195846-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000
Case Type:
FOIPA
Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)

The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.

You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.


Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Our complex requests are further divided into small (51-250 pages), medium (251-500 pages), large (501-4,999), and extra-large (over 5,000 pages) sub-tracks.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing. Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.
Currently, simple track cases average approximately 230 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Complex requests in the small processing track are currently averaging 1,085 days from the date of receipt for processing, those in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,310 days, those in the large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and those in the extra-large track are averaging 2,370 days  .


Respectfully,

Public Information Officer

200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Sheriff Data Collection Request (2016-2021)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by year, from 2016-2021 (for example, 302 use of force incidents in 2016, 287 use of force incidents in 2021, etc.)

2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force and year used from 2016-2020 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2016, baton incidents in 2016, etc.). Please include as part of this a breakdown of how many use of force incidents in each year were related to law enforcement operations and how many were related to correctional/custodial operations.

When available, I would appreciate being sent individualized data for each item in this request in spreadsheet format. If individualized data are unavailable, please send information that includes aggregate statistics for the item instead.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: P001622-122222
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
Dear Samuel Sinyangwe, On December 22, 2022, the San Francisco Sheriff's Office received your request for records pursuant to the California Public Records Act (CPRA) wherein you requested the records below. Our responses are listed below: 

1. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by year, from 2016-2021 (for example, 302 use of force incidents in 2016, 287 use of force incidents in 2021, etc.) Response: Please log in to view the document that shows the use of force totals by year and month. 

2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force and year used from 2016-2020 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2016, baton incidents in 2016, etc.). Please include as part of this a breakdown of how many use of force incidents in each year were related to law enforcement operations and how many were related to correctional/custodial operations. Response:  There are no responsive records for this portion of your request as the SFSO does not perform a use of force analysis with a breakdown by type of force or by law enforcement and custodial operations. 

Your request is now closed. 
Sincerely, 
Johna Pecot, Retired Chief Deputy 
San Francisco Sheriff's Office 
Central Records & Warrants Unit

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Boston Office Of The Mayor RTO Return to Office Communications 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Email messages and message contents with the keywords "RTO" or "Return to Office" in the email message subject or message body within the last calendar year.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brandon Galbraith

12/18/2023 RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of December 03, 2023., Reference # R004372-120323 Dear Brandon Galbraith: The City of Boston (City) has received your request for public records.  This response applies only to records that exist and are in the custody of the City. See A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, p. 32, n.115.  It is expected that a custodian of records must use her superior knowledge of her records with respect to responses to public records requests.  950 CMR 32.04(5).  Specifically, you stated: 
To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

Email messages and message contents with the keywords "RTO" or "Return to Office" in the email message subject or message body within the last calendar year. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage. 

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Brandon Galbraith 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fmayors-office-11%252Fboston-office-of-the-mayor-rto-return-to-office-communications-2023-155476%252F%253Femail%253Dpublicrecords%252540boston.gov&url_auth_token=AAAdDuXbNtQ5WK4ci5ISdu1gtRc%3A1r9zk4%3Av-sZyYxdGBQjooP9QJjulUVAt5q4N8JC1YN52QHRyao A response to a public records request must be provided within ten (10) business days from the business day a written request was received.  G. L. c. 66, § 10 (a); 950 CMR 32.06(2)(b).  The public records law permits a response time of up to twenty-five (25) business days from the business day a written request is received, so long as a detailed explanation is provided.  G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(vi); 950 CMR 32.06(2)(i). Due to the nature of your request additional time is needed.  As such, the City will need up to, but no more than, fifteen (15) additional business days to review and process your request. Very truly yours, Bianca V. Crockett, Esq. Assistant Corporation Counsel City of Boston One City Hall Square Boston, MA 02201

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: CPs - State
communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

any memos, emails, text messages, images or other material that reference the "Belarusian Cyber Partisans," or the "Cyber Partisans," between the dates of Sept. 20, 2020 and May 5, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

AJ Vicens

communications.subject: Ref: F-2022-08010, Freedom of Information Act Response
communications.communication: **THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.** Mr.Vicens: This email responds to yourMay 6, 2022, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552) request received by the U.S. Department of State,Office of Information Programs and Services on May 6, 2022, regarding all records - memos, emails, text messages, images or other material that reference the "Belarusian Cyber Partisans," or the "Cyber Partisans." (Date Range for Record Search: From 9/20/2020 To 5/5/2022). This Office assigned your request the subject reference number. This Office denies your request, as currently written, because itdoes not reasonably describe the records sought.  request mustreasonably describe the Department records that are sought to enable Departmentpersonnel to begin a search for responsive records. Such details may include the subject,timeframe, names of any individuals involved, a contract number (ifapplicable), and reasons why the requester believes the Department may haverecords regarding the subject of the request. See 22 CFR 171.4(b). If you are not satisfied with thisOffice’s determination in response to your request, you may administrativelyappeal to: Appeals Officer, Office of InformationPrograms and Services, U.S. Department of State, 2201 C Street, NW, Room B266,Washington, D.C. 20520; or facsimile at 202-485-1718. Your appeal must be postmarked orelectronically transmitted within 90 days of the date of this email. If you have any questionsregarding your request, please contact our FOIA Requester Service Center or ourFOIA Public Liaison by email at FOIAstatus@state.gov or telephone at 202-261-8484.  Additionally, youmay contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at theNational Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIAmediation services they offer. Thecontact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government InformationServices, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS,College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, email at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. Sincerely, J.Turman, for Kellie N. Robinson Chief, Requester Liaison Division (Acting) FOIA Program Manager/FOIA Public Liaison U.S. Department of State Office of Information Programs and Services **THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.**

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #F-2022-08010
communications.communication:
Appeals Officer 
Office of Information Programs and Services 
U.S. Department of State 
2201 C Street, NW, Room B266, Washington, D.C., 20520

I would like to appeal the letter I received  saying that my FOIA request "does not reasonably describe the records sought." The denial — issued just five days after my request was submitted — noted that "the request must reasonably describe the Department records that are sought to enable Department personnel to begin a search for responsive records. Such details may include the subject, timeframe, names of any individuals involved ... "

My request asked for any records related the "Belarusian Cyber Partisans," or the "Cyber Partisans," which refers to a narrow and specific group and/or subject. I also specifically asked for "any records - memos, emails, text messages, images or other material," which seems to be a clear and reasonable description of possible search options.  

Therefore I believe that I very narrowly constructed my request to a limited number of records that would relate to the stated subject. It is inappropriate for this agency to issue such a letter so quickly after receiving the request. Please instruct the FOIA officers to complete a search for records before making such a determination.

In the spirit of good faith, the only thing I neglected to add was a time frame. Please search for material dated between Jan. 1, 2020 and May 11, 2022.

Thank you,
AJ Vicens

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All dash cam and body cam footage from responding officers, as well as a copy of the arrest report related to the arrest of Amber Marie Bingham on 9/5/24.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

C H

communications.subject: Re: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Amber Bingham
communications.communication:
Good morning; 

Hope you are doing well today. 

Unfortunately, we do not have any records for a Amber Marie Bingham. 

Ms. Bingham does not have any arrests, offenses, traffic citations, domestic, gang referrals or any other relevant information in our records management system. 

However, Acworth borders four (4) counties, meaning they all have Acworth addresses, but are not in the Municipal City of Acworth (where you made the request). 

Bartow, Cherokee, Cobb and Paulding counties all have Acworth address, but are not in the City of Acworth. 

If you can tell me the address, I can pinpoint the Agency. 

This will complete your request. 

Hope you have a great week! 

With kind regards, 

Dori Askew 
Records Division

Thanks so much for the quick reply. Acworth PD is the arresting agency on record in the booking info for the incident dated 9/5/24. Can we check for Amber Marie King rather than Bingham?

Thank you.

communications.subject: Re: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Amber Bingham
communications.communication:
Hi; 

Hope you are doing well. 

Jackpot! It was under King, Amber....the report is attached. 

Unfortunately, this has not gone to court yet and is pending prosecution, so I'm unable to give you the videos on this case. 



Per O.C.G.A. 50-18-72 (a) (4), Records in an active investigation or PENDING PROSECUTION, other than initial public arrest reports and initial incident reports, are NOT required to be released. 
This will complete your request. 

Hope you have a great week.

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: New Jersey LIHTC QCs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of developments that have exited the state's LIHTC program through the qualified contract process since 2010, sufficient to show:

1) The name, full address, and ownership of all such developments
2) The total number of low-income units in all such developments
3) The year in which the decontrol period of all such developments ended (or year the qualified contract was requested, if this is not available)

I am a journalist with In These Times magazine, a nonprofit outlet based at 2040 N Milwaukee Ave in Chicago, IL.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rebecca Burns

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Video Request | CRB2400522, Novak, Steven
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

This is a request for DASHCAM and BWC video for the first two squads on scene and any subsequent BWC video related to the arrest of the primary suspect in this matter. (As a formality, this request is being made under open records statutes governing this data.)

Please also include the police report from the primary officer or the probable cause statement. You can exclude any PII. The narrative is the most important part. 

If the individual was NOT arrested on camera, please let us know as we will likely cancel the request. 

Suspect Name: Novak, Steven
Date of Birth: 1959/10/25
Pinella County Court Case Number: CRB2400522
Filing Date: 2024-07-24
Offense Date: 2024-07-12
Description: Poss. Drug Para

IF YOUR AGENCY DOES NOT USE BODY CAMERAS:
If you do not have a body camera video related to this incident, please let us know. We will likely cancel the request if your agency was not using BWC at the time of the incident. (Exception: State Troopers - we will still want state trooper dash cams.)

EXCLUDED FROM THIS REQUEST:
Exclude any portion of footage involving personally identifiable information (PII)
Exclude portions of the video in which minors are visible
Exclude portions involving nudity, explicit or graphic content (blur, redact, or cut)
Exclude any other portion of the video at your discretion. 

Thank you in advance for any consideration,
Allison Wheeler | Volunteer

communications.subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request: CORA Logs (Cherry Hills Village City Clerk)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Colorado Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am submitting a Colorado Open Records Act (CORA) request seeking access to specific documents related to your department's activities for the 180 day period preceding today, from Friday, February 9, 2024, to Wednesday, August 7, 2024. Specifically, I am requesting:

1. All records of CORA requests sent to your department during the specified 180 day period.
2. All records of CORA responses issued by your department in response to external requests within the same timeframe.
3. A copy of the fee schedule for processing CORA requests and any associated costs.
4. A copy of your department's open records policy for reference.
5.Correspondence in relationship to CORA requests sent between government entities.

Please include details such as dates, requestors' names, and request contents in the CORA records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Newton

Our records request fees are $8 per 15 minutes after the first hour of staff time, per the attached records request fee schedule (page 2 of the attached PDF). Are you able to pay all fees or would you like as many records as can be gathered within a certain amount of time?

Thank you,

Laura Gillespie

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: University of California Davis PRA Databases
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1 — any databases and/or spreadsheets used to track requests under the California Public Records Act for the last 5 years from the date of this request.
2 — any and all policy documents, manuals, memos and/or reports regarding the processing of public records requests for the last 5 years from the date of this request.

In the regard to the database requested in paragraph 1, please provide the database in its original electronic format pursuant to Cal. Gov. Code § 6253.9.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ed Burton

title: Requesting MCAS tests and items (Department Of Elementary And Secondary Education)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Requesting MCAS tests and items (Department Of Elementary And Secondary Education)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all MCAS tests and items administered since its inception in 1993, organized by subject, grade level, and date of administration, *including* whether those items were used as part of test or MCAS re-test/re-take.

This material is being request for an educational purpose, specifically the analysis and exploration of test composition over time as part of a high school's education mission.

The Public Records Law requires you to provide me with a written response within 10 business days. If you cannot comply with my request, you are statutorily required to provide an explanation in writing.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alec Resnick

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request #P004199-081324
communications.communication: Hi again! I just wanted to check in on this inquiry?

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request #P004199-081324
communications.communication: Hi again! Could I please get an update on the status of this inquiry?

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P004199-081324
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Hi Alec, 
The test questions that we have publicly released are available through this page: https://www.doe.mass.edu/mcas/testitems.html 
The test questions that we have not released are being kept for future use and are covered under exemption L of the public records law: questions and answers, scoring keys and sheets and other materials used to develop, administer or score a test, examination or assessment instrument; provided, however, that such materials are intended to be used for another test, examination or assessment instrument. The purpose of Exemption (l) is to prevent individuals from gaining an unfair advantage by using the Public Records Law to access test questions and answers prior to the administration of an examination. 
Best wishes, 
Jackie Reis 
jacqueline.reis@mass.gov

title: Correspondence records: operation to capture of Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada, July 25, 2024

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Correspondence records: operation to capture of Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada, July 25, 2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of correspondence to and from the ONDCP documenting the operation that delivered Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada to the United States for arrest on July 25, 2024.

These records would be contained within the system of records with the name "Correspondence Management systems (CMS) for the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP)" and number "ONDCP/001."

Records could be identified by a search for records dating from July 12 to July 26 which are responsive to the following text strings:

"Joaquin Guzman Lopez"  also known as "Guero Moreno" and "Guero"
"Ismael Zambada" also known as "El Mayo" or simply "Mayo."

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

communications.subject: FOIA 2024209
communications.communication:
Attached please find ONDCP’s response to your request.

Sandy Slater
White House Office of National Drug Control Policy
Direct: (202) 395-6622
Email: sslater@ondcp.eop.gov<mailto:sslater@ondcp.eop.gov>

files.title: ONDCP2024209 Reply ltr
files.source: Office of National Drug Control Policy, United States of America

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #FOIA 2024209
communications.communication:
I formally appeal the decision of the Office of National Drug Control Policy in FOIA# 2024209 ("operation to capture of Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada, July 25, 2024"). 

I must express skepticism that there are no communications either sent or received by the Office regarding the arrest of two persons named in the 2024 National Drug Threat Assessment. Further, the ONDCP produced at least one public statement regarding the arrests, indicating it was notified of the arrest and had prepared comments. See: https://x.com/ONDCP/status/1816846123622928782

My prayer for relief is that the Office conduct a proper search and return responsive material.

-TM

On Aug. 15, 2024:
Subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #FOIA 2024209
I formally appeal the decision of the Office of National Drug Control Policy in FOIA# 2024209 ("operation to capture of Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada, July 25, 2024").

I must express skepticism that there are no communications either sent or received by the Office regarding the arrest of two persons named in the 2024 National Drug Threat Assessment. Further, the ONDCP produced at least one public statement regarding the arrests, indicating it was notified of the arrest and had prepared comments. See: https://x.com/ONDCP/status/1816846123622928782

My prayer for relief is that the Office conduct a proper search and return responsive material.

-TM
---

On Aug. 15, 2024:
Subject: FOIA 2024209
Attached please find ONDCP’s response to your request.

Sandy Slater
White House Office of National Drug Control Policy
Direct: (202) 395-6622
Email: sslater@ondcp.eop.gov<mailto:sslater@ondcp.eop.gov<mailto:sslater@ondcp.eop.gov%3cmailto:sslater@ondcp.eop.gov>>

---

On July 26, 2024:
Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Correspondence records: operation to capture of Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada, July 25, 2024
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of correspondence to and from the ONDCP documenting the operation that delivered Joaquin Guzman Lopez and Ismael Zambada to the United States for arrest on July 25, 2024.

These records would be contained within the system of records with the name "Correspondence Management systems (CMS) for the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP)" and number "ONDCP/001."

Records could be identified by a search for records dating from July 12 to July 26 which are responsive to the following text strings:

"Joaquin Guzman Lopez" also known as "Guero Moreno" and "Guero"
"Ismael Zambada" also known as "El Mayo" or simply "Mayo."

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Fire Island Marine Serivce LLC -Inspection 1709320.015
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

This request concerns Inspection 1709320.015 and Report ID 0214700 concerning Fire Island Marine Services LLC at location 99 Maple Avenue Bay Shore, New York. 11706, which investigation was opened Nov. 8th 2023.  Request is made for the following documents,
1. All citations or penalties issued to the Employer,  Fire Island Marine Services LLC as a result of the investigation and final disposition including appeals and including amounts paid.
2. All investigation reports, findings, and conclusions on which the citations and penalties were based. 
3. All correspondence between OSHA and the Employer Fire Island Marine Services.
4. All photographs, videos, or other media related to the investigation.
5. All witness statements or memoranda, interviews conducted as part of the investigation. whether reduced to writing or recorded.
6. All communications from the Employer Fire Island Marine Services concerning Abatement or documentation of abatement.


Tabak , Mellusi & Shisha is not a Commercial use requester, nor is it an  Educational institution, noncommercial scientific institution, or representative of the news media.

Sincerely 

Tabak Mellusi & Shisha

By Ralph J. Mellusi

29 Broadway Suite 2400
New York, N.Y. 10006
Office Tel 212 962-1590
Office Fax 212 385-0920

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

RALPH Mellusi

communications.subject: Fire Island Marine Services #1709320
communications.communication:
This is in response to your Freedomof Information request received in our office on 8/30/24 requesting the abovementioned file.  This record is nowavailable and has been enclosed for your information. You will note some informationhas been removed from the documents. This is authorized under the rules and regulations, includingexemptions, contained in the Freedom of Information Act and 29 CFR Part 70.  Actual sections deleted are indicated onAttachment #1, with numbered exemptions noted in each case.  For specific numbers and wording ofexemptions, please refer to Attachment #2 You have the right to appeal this decision with theSolicitor of Labor within 90 days from the date of this letter.  Theappeal must state, in writing, the grounds for the appeal, including anysupporting statements or arguments.  The appeal should also include a copyof your initial request and a copy of this letter. If you appeal, you may mail your appeal to: Solicitor ofLabor, U.S. Department of Labor, Room N-2420, 200 Constitution Avenue, N.W.,Washington, D.C. 20210 or fax your appeal to (202) 693-5538. Alternatively, you may email your appeal to foiaappeal@dol.gov (mailto:foiaappeal@dol.gov) ;appeals submitted to any other email address will not be accepted.  Theenvelope (if mailed), subject line (if emailed), or fax cover sheet (if faxed),and the letter indicating the grounds for appeal, should be clearly marked:“Freedom of Information Act Appeal.” In additio to filing anAppeal, you may contact the Department’s FOIA Public Liaison, Thomas G. Hicks,Sr. at (202) 693-5427 or hicks.thomas@dol.gov (mailto:hicks.thomas@dol.gov) for assistance in resolving disputes. You also may contact the Office of Government InformationServices (OGIS) for assistance.  OGIS offers mediation services to resolvedisputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusivealternative to litigation.  Using OGIS services does not affect your rightto pursue litigation.  You may mail OGIS at the Office of GovernmentInformation Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601Adelphi Road – OGIS, College Park, MD 20740-6001. Alternatively, you may email or contact OGIS through itswebsite at: ogis@nara.gov (mailto:ogis@nara.gov) ; Web: https://ogis.archives.gov (https://ogis.archives.gov/) .  Finally,you can call or fax OGIS at: telephone: (202) 741-5770; toll-free:1-877-684-6448. It is also important to note that the services offered byOGIS, is not an alternative to filing an administrative FOIA appeal. If we can be of further assistance to you, please feel freeto contact this office at 516-334-3344 or reply to this email. Enclosure ATTACHMENT #1 
Re:       Fire Island Marine Services 
#1709320 
Listing ofdeletions: Partial Deletions: (302 Pagesreleased) 
Complete Deletions: Pages 48,186,206,222,236,234,236,238,240,242,244, 246,248,250,252,272,288,294,296,298,300,302,304,306,308 (25 pages)- Blank 
Pages 121-135 (15 pages)- Employee Incident Report- Ex. 4,7c 

ATTACHMENT #2 Most used exemptions paragraphs from 5 U.S.C. Section 552(b): 
#4                  Information that is classifiedas trade secrets and/or of commercial or financial value obtained from a personand is privileged or a confidential source of information. 
#5                  Inter-agency or intra-agencymemorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party otherthan an agency in litigation with the Agency. 
#6                  This exclusion is intended toexclude from disclosure all personal and medical files, and all private orpersonal information contained in other files which, if disclosed to thepublic, would amount to a clearly unwarranted invasion of the privacy of anyperson, including members of the family of the person to whom the informationpertains. 
#7                  Information contained ininvestigatory files complied for law enforcement purposes except to the extentavailable by law to a party other than an agency. 
#7(C)            Information pertaining to theprivacy interests of individuals, including                        information about anindividual which he could reasonably assert an option to withhold from thepublic at large because of its intimacy or its possible adverse effect uponhimself or his family. 
#7(D)            The identification of a confidentialsource or confidential information furnished by a confidential source.

Dear Records Requestor:


Your request for information from the New Mexico Educational Retirement Board was forwarded to me. In accordance with the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act (IPRA), “a written request shall provide the name, address and telephone number of the person seeking access to the records and shall identify the records sought with reasonable particularity.” Section 14-2-8(C) NMSA 1978.


If you will provide me with your name and mailing address, we can begin the process of allowing inspection of the relevant records.


The Inspection of Public Records Act can be found at 14-2-1 through 14-2-12 NMSA 1978.


Thank you.


Amanda Olsen

Dear Ms. Rock,

I am responding to your email yesterday requesting any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request. Please be assured that we make every effort to respond promptly to every request. However, we must also ensure that we are diligent and accurate in our reply. Thus, when obtained, all documents and emails must be reviewed. Additionally, we must rely on the state agency that controls the entire state email system to identify and provide the emails requested. As you can imagine, the process takes time.

As to an estimated response date, in our letter of August 1, 2023, we noted that we intend to respond by September 6, 2023.

Thank you for your patience and please feel free to contact me if you have further questions.

Respectfully,

[cid:image001.png@01D9C623.0D3F7D80]

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hello Ms. Garcia,

Thank you for the update. Given that it's now been five months since we filed the initial request, are you able to provide an update as to whether you've identified the responsive documents, or what the source of the delay is?

Thank you,

Rebecca

communications.subject: ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGED - RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

Thank you for your inquiry and please accept our apologies for the delay.

As Mr. Scroggins noted in his August 3, 2023 email regarding our projected response, we always try to be prompt.  But as you might guess, the request references a large number of records.  As he said, we must thoroughly review all records to identify and obtain the responsive documents from both external and internal sources.  It is a complex and time-consuming process.

I am confident that we will have documents ready to provide on or before the December 6th, 2023, date noted in our recent communication.

Thank you for your continued patience!
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image002.png@01DA121F.C2136CB0]

files.source: New Mexico Educational Retirement Board, New Mexico

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence

Thanks so much for your help with this request! I really appreciate it.

Sincerely,
Julia Rock

communications.subject: Re: Request for Inspection of Records
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns:

As discussed in our letter of December 6, 2023, we are providing the records we currently have available in response to your June 16, 2023, request.  They are located at the website below:

MuckRock - Julia Rock<https://nmgov-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/r/personal/renee_garcia_erb_nm_gov/Documents/MuckRock%20-%20Julia%20Rock?csf=1&web=1&e=4gwfSH>

As also discussed, we will require additional time to provide the remainder of the records.  We plan to provide additional documents on or before February 1, 2024.  Thank you again for your continued patience regarding this matter.
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image001.png@01DA29F0.5D899B00]

MuckRock Staff

Renee

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any annual, quarterly, or semesterly logs or reports that detail how often carious school therapy services are provided to students. Please provide logs from the academic year beginning in 2014 through the present.

Any reports, logs, or other data that tracks average wait times for students who have sought help for mental health issues. Please provide logs from the academic year beginning in 2014 through the present.

The budget for mental health services for each year beginning in 2014 through the present.

Any reports, logs, or other data that tracks the number of mental health accommodations requested each school year, as well as the outcomes of those accommodation requests. Please provide records beginning in 2014 through the present. 

Any and all policies related to mental health, including but not limited to policies governing leaves of absence (voluntary and involuntary) for students, as well as any logs or reports that note the voluntary and involuntary leaves of absences students have taken each year since 2014.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jennifer Costo

communications.subject: RE: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
Ms. Costo -

We are continuing to work to resolve the request that you've submitted.  We have encountered some issues as many of the staff that would have been charged with compiling some of the studies requested are unavailable due to the Coronavirus outbreak.  We have not been able to have the majority of our staff on campus since noon on March 19th.  Under the circumstances, we will need additional time.

Please feel free to reach out with additional questions.

Jeffrey Herron

communications.subject: RE: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following New Jersey Open Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on March 16, 2020. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
Good afternoon, Ms. Costo -

We are still operating under Executive Orders which have kept the majority of our employee base off campus due to the Coronavirus pandemic.  We are hopeful that these restrictions will be lifted soon, and that our employees will be in a position to respond to the request.  I will provide you an update no later than July 23rd as to the status of your request, and will certainly respond sooner if we are in a position to fulfill it.

Jeffrey Herron

communications.subject: RE: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
Good morning -

The College is in receipt of your request.  As you are likely aware, the College is currently operating remotely due to the COVID-19 public health emergency.  Consistent with other public agencies, we are encountering difficulties responding to Public Records requests within the typical timeframe.  We would request an extension on this request to September 30, 2020 to allow our staff time to coordinate and provide the information to meet your query.  Personnel continue to be off campus that we will need to work with to provide your information, as an initial cursory review has not been able to locate materials within your request.

Please feel free to reach out with any questions.

Jeffrey Herron

communications.subject: RE: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
Good morning –

The College is in receipt of this update request.  This is a matter that prompted numerous challenges during the timeframe that the request was made – the outset of the pandemic, coupled with the move of the College to remote operations for a significant period.

In the time that has passed there has also been turnover of oversight personnel in this area, along with an organizational restructuring of the College, with the creation of a Student and Enrollment Services Division at the macro level and a reconsideration of the reporting structure for the Counseling department within that Division.

The College would request an extension of time to provide responsive documents in this matter, during which time it will also assess requirements under the Open Public Records Act.  Any responsive documents provided will be for the timeframe considered under the original request.

The College will provide an update as to the status of this request no later than Thursday, August 8th, 2024.

[cid:image001.png@01DAB650.2C89FAD0]
Jeffrey Herron
Vice President, Institutional Effectiveness, Planning and Compliance

communications.subject: RE: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Middlesex County Community College OPRA
communications.communication:
Good morning –

The following are our responsive documents to your request –

Any annual, quarterly, or semesterly logs or reports that detail how often various school therapy services are provided to students. Please provide logs from the academic year beginning in 2014 through the present.

  *   Middlesex College currently provides short-term confidential counseling to our students on campus or via telehealth through UWill. If the needs of students require help from outside providers, appropriate referrals have been made. Prior to 2021, mental health services were provided through our Counseling and Disabilities office and the data was not disaggregated by services provided.  ​
Data from January 21 through December of 2 2 is in the attached “Counseling Center Tracker” document.
Any reports, logs, or other data that tracks average wait times for students who have sought help for mental health issues. Please provide logs from the academic year beginning in 2014 through the present.

  *   Between 2014 and 2020, the Middlesex College Counseling and Disabilities office used a third party software that did not track average student wait times.
The budget for mental health services for each year beginning in 2014. (I can’t see below 2020 on Student Services)
Counseling Budget 113100
FY 2021 – 1,246,036
FY 2020 – 1,280,921
Any reports, logs, or other data that tracks the number of mental health accommodations requested each school year, as well as the outcomes of those accommodation requests. Please provide records beginning in 2014 through the present.

  *   Mental health accommodations are not tracked separately from other accommodations that were provided by our Counseling and Disabilities Office. There is no outcome data on file.

Any and all policies related to mental health, including but not limited to policies governing leaves of absence (voluntary and involuntary) for students, as well as any logs or reports that note the voluntary and involuntary leaves of absences students have taken each year since 2014.


  *   Information regarding policies related to mental health can be found through this link:
https://middlesexcollege.edu/student-life/counseling-services/
https://middlesexcollege.edu/about/college-leadership/board-of-trustees/policy-manual/
  *   Leave of Absence link:
https://www.course-catalog.com/mcc/C/2024-2025/content/enrollment-services-college-programs-and-activities/leave-of-absence/54

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: John "Sonny" Franzese Sr.
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Files, memos, emails and other records mentioning or describing John "Sonny" Franzese Sr. (February 6, 1917 – February 24, 2020), who was an Italian-American mobster who was a longtime member of the Colombo crime family.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Best
